element_texts.text: of passengers.  unclear got unclear Pawnee Res Mr Egan on board got sleeping berth - his nom de Gurerre - got Maura/Maida? to buy them The [?] people were savy same for ladies - Mr. Hand on board used to know him as Sanders  Introduced

all night  - lost my pipe  -  & a bot of whiskey leaked out - also  left my big knife.  Extremely hot day  May 7- Passed a poor night from heat - Luckily a norther sprang up & about 3 oclk I crept under a blanket  Breakfast at Sidney   Met Egan - & others

8th - Went down to Ben  Moore & got my horses both of all right.  Moore very accommodating - Long talk on hunting - wrote to Fasteu  Ma P & to Tooky  - went to Town & saw Mr Jenney - also the Herald reporter Mr Davenport - Telegraphed to Genl Crook about guides & packers - Mr Jenney seems very good man. appa

9th  Bar? good by unclear at 8.00AM  Took Genl Bradleys spring wagon.  (?Mules?) look badly but travel unclear or the distances are greatly overrated - Arrived Horse Creek 25 miles 12.15 or 3 3/4 hours - Left H Creek at 1.45 & reached Phillips ranch on unclear at 5.15 - 25 miles - ?Total? distance said to be 50 miles made it in 7.15 - unclear

10th - Started 7.35.  Twenty one miles at 10.20 - arrived at Fort Laramie- 1.45 pm Road bad along the (unclear) but good over the hills -  Disappointed in appearance of post.  Went to Genl Bradleys reported - stop (unclear) met many Officers & old  Col Bullock a 4th Col of mine from Virginia  Sutter? here from time immemorial & the advent? of Belknap - Called on Genl Bradley at night - much

what was left in (unclear) City - Must have a guide & if possible one or two Indians. Most not go by the (?Agencies?)   Informed persons all tell me
it is far out of the way. - Bed at 10 pm slept well - Phillips is a Portugese from the  Azores

walk when he arrived -Saw all the offs - played Billiards.  Had talk with Collins post Trader - Breakfasted with Nix   12. Telegrams from all parts - One from John Adair, wanting to go with me - answered by tel - also by letter - Tel from Secy of War about Collins. his spirituous outfit -  Yesterday rec'd tel from Tooty & answered it   Telegraphed to Jenney

his two sisters in law: Misses Dewey - nice girls - went over to see Nix? Sister Lady as charming as ever.  Met lots of Officers - Dont even know their names yet.  11th - Slept well - up at 8 am paid Official call on Commdg Offr He has no orders for me - Telegraphed to (?Ruggles?) about guides & packers - Recd answer that Genl C would attend

Platte - Capt Hawley & 4 col ordered our scout - ferry very bad - all day getting over - Telegram from (?Trout?) saying he can be here by 20th- answered by telegram.  Am doing nothing here - can do nothing until [?Trout?] & Genl C arrive -  13th - Did a large amt of nothing today  visited Mrs Nix in Evening

about horses.  Tomorro is mail day.  Wrote letters to Tooky Father & others- Dined with Genl Bradley- today - But did not stop long after dinner. Played billiards & went to bed

late   12 - went after the Qr Mr about my outfit   Rode up to the cavalry camp, a mile up the

top line cut off in scan
to ranch of (unclear)  15.  same routine Genl Crook to arrive  tomorro -   16 - about 2pm   Genl ? Nickerson? & Burke arrived - went over to see Genl in afternoon - Had a very satisfactory interview -& got pretty nearly all I wanted from him   Called on him at night-   17 - Saw Genl again got a few more things

met many offs - played  billiards - gassed & went to bed late -  14th, moved my horses to Spaulding's stable Got my things together-  Qr Mr has only 50 wagons
for me - very scant supply for such a trip -  Saw Genl B about ammunition - Spaulding & Col Bullock went

18 - Front arrived - Too sick with cold to do much today.  Tho I went to the Genl Bradley & got my ordnance - 12 Howitzer or Gatling guns got my unclear started, but a tortoise is rapid to that workman Tel - from Jenney - His party will be here on Thursday  or Friday Am to get my comd?

Genl left for Robinson about 12 m - Burke going with me a topographical affair?- Took a bad cold somehow - Nothing new - A good deal of  excitement about (unclear) of course - Got 10  wagons more out of the  genl - am pretty well fixed now -

up - (unclear) at work like a mace - Visited Mrs ? at night - also called on Genl Bradley - Passed a rather (unclear) birth day - Mail arrived bringing several letters One from Tooty, another from Father & Mother  Wrote letters in evening to both them & several friends - wrote to (unclear) telling him not to come

tomorro - unclearon my birth day - & hope to be ready to get away before 25th   19th woke up with the terrible cold still hanging on - Order was issued designating the Col to go with me.  Spaulding packing

Gave my attention to the men working at my unclear - very slow.  Chairs nearly done - Stop at night - did not go spent evening writing letter to Tooky then went to Collins to get him to take it - He promised to call on her at Omaha Nka - She is en route to Washington on the Indian question

come to me to Blackman? telling him to come sure -   20th - Still suffering from an awful cold - Janny? & party arrived quite early - put them in the camp above / unclear
unclear at work - all the forage loaded or put across river.

& can start in an hour  No news of (unclear) - Hired "California Joe" as packer Staff of Expedition   unclear took 9th unclear: Inf?--?  unclear 23 unclear   unclear Burke unclear   22 - Slept better but cold still very bad racking me with cough.  Loaded up my ordnance & got the guns in order also got my Sub--?? stores

21 - Terribly racked with cough during night & in morning - Genl B issued order relieving all my COs from duty at post  unclear loaded & got all the Com'p stores over river .
Issued orders [[crossing?}} Com'p Cattle over river - Bad job - hard work - but finally all swam but two (2) which had to be killed -- Packed up my things

am." for one comfy Burke paid $30 to unclear  Com'p Bill -- Wrote to Tooty at night. A mail goes off tomorro.   23rd sent off letters early cold bad but better --  Paymaster? & all visitors went east. Orders for the (unclear) in the morning. across river.  Guide to be here tonight

Called on all the Ladies in evening - My unclear pay-t - & uncleararrived.  Drew $10.50 for exps from Omaha to Ft Laramie - Got all my ambulances - Everythingready except Guide. My potatoes?.  Scouts? clothing & some

Guide arrived yesterday. Discharged "California Joe" for drunkenness -  Hired a man named Duffele --camped on bank of Platte 1/2 mile above ferry - very good camp. Got everything over. Issued my marching & camp order. Had a pleasant evening & went to bed early - Jenney & scientists got over about 5 pm - all ready for start in the morning - except that the photographer has not arrived?

Can't hear of potatoes ? Geologist Jenney will be ready to start Tuesday  25 - visited Gnr Bradley & all the ladies at night -   24th - up pretty early & got all packed. Infy Co
got over river quick -early. I went down with Spaulding Co. Mix Nix? wife & sister came to see us off - also Genl B & many of the officers.

second plain . plenty of sand & some mud from rain on 23d.  Heavy hauling for unclear- most delightful day for marching. Camped on Rawhide at 1.30 pm. 16 miles from last camp - Everything travelled well - caught some chubs? & late in evening went out & shot some doves -- Officers very agreeable & efficient - Had nice unclear - Several officers visiting me - Good camp. Water grass & wood.

neither have  unclear baggage on my potatoes & onion - Left unclear 6 men & wagon to bring up Phot & mail   25th  up at 4 am.  unclear's first night in tent - got scared during sleep - accused his Dad of snoring  Broke camp 6 am. Comy's wagons heavily loaded & took a long time to get started - good march over an undulating country - unclear

build a bridge - Followed up Rawhide by a trail hugging the hills - a good deal of work necessary on road - At crossing of the other stream Joe Merivale? told me that it was the Main Rawhide, that this stream we followed was a dry fork, that the main stream made a great bend & we would save some miles by the cut off, a camp

26th  Broke camp 6 am Adv guard left 5.45 & I went with it. Merivale? left road & passed to the west over a sandy cactus prairie & had to come back to road unclear to cross creek - crossed with little work  at 8.20 crossed a tributary from north part of unclear crossed on natural bottom which cut deep & we had to

Sent courier to stop wagons & sending the  unclear found F-unclear to make camp on Rawhide.  I took a couple of orderlies & went on the unclear to look for a proper crossing.  My faith in Merivale? is gone & I must myself play guide.  Followed division? to Rawhide Butte Struck Mex? trail & followed it back to camp.  Saw

on main Rawhide - left trail & struck up a dry fork from the north - sand deep & travelling abominable  2 1/2 miles up o came to me & said he was mistaken & that we had passed the water on which we ought to camp & that the nearest water unclear- north? was the Niobrara 15 miles at least  I turned back at once

wagon I left behind for photographer - potatoes & onions & unclear: Scout's clothes? Trout ?? Brought mail.  Letter for Tooty - very comforting - wrote to her, to Father & Mother - private - report to Genls Crook & Bradley - Bush-hunter killed antelope & unclear the saddle.  Rain in evening.  Having a nice time every [[way?] my Com'p very fine --

the lay of the land & shade/shale? have no difficulty tomorro? except in crossing ravines - Joe feels very badly so I do not blow him up - Nice camp at junction of Dry fork with main Rawhide  Good wood water & grass. Distance made 7 1/2 miles distance lost 5 miles total march only 12 1/2 mi and very trying on the unclear  Men arrived with the

by compass. Merivale said I could not get through -- Found a splendid route except a few bad ravines which had to be worked.  The Rawhide range of hills is very fine & we passed through a lovely & most picturesque country  None of the maps even indicate the characteristics of the range & the water shed.  About 11 struck an old trail

27th  Started with Adv gd. 5:30 am - Camp broke at 545 - Followed Mix Trail to the great disgust of Joe Menivale who wanted to experiment? with me & Com'p on detour? I knew both & took trail.  Excellent south to Rawhide Butte Then some pretty rough ravines were crossed - As soon as I had fairly turned? The Butte I struck north

nothing but brush - The day has been very cold - wore my Canada over coat all day with comfort  Country passed through today very attractive - Sent off mail by Baptiste  the Ft Laramie guide who was sent out to me for that purpose by Genl Bradley - who had done all that could be done in kindness & consideration for our comfort -

supposed to be Raynold's of unclear-- If so it is exactly what I want. Reached the Niobrara by a most excellent route at 12.40.  Every one is delighted with the route and I have had many congratulations on my performance as guide.  Distance 20 miles.  Excellent camp fine water & grass but wood very scarce.

that I went to bed at 8.30 to keep warm -  28th - Camp 5. Slept well. Very cold during night- Heavy frost & ice formed in tents - Adv Guard & I started at 5.30 am - Comp 6 - followed old Indian trail which led in direction  unclear.  The wagon trail followed yesterday gave out. Discovered that Raynold's Engr? was never in this country

to make my expedition a success - Everything is going on admirably & my officers seem to vie with each other in doing all I desire - Niobrara belies its name "running water" where I struck it, but soon begins to run in a nice little stream. It has been very cold all day & tomorro evening it became so much worse

got very high at last. When we suddenly came to a steep pitch from the top of which is one of the most splendid views I have seen -0 the whole valley of "Old Woman" creek spread out at our feet bounded by steep crags high rounded hills covered with pine & in the distance the haven of our hopes "The Black HIlls"

but marked the route on this map from description of a guide at Ft Laramie.  No wagons have ever been here except small light affairs traving with Indians.  For 9 miles this am the road was very fine passing over long divides seperating waters of the Niabrara.  The ground

our troubles began. A few days ago, there was a very severe rain storm here & the overlower? valley is now in most places a bog.  While the little creek which one can step across looms with formidable force? perilous for a wagon train, requiring to be bridged every little way. Our work was slow & tedious in the extreme.  Going down in this way for about four miles

The country is most lovely and I don't blame the Indians for wishing to hold on to it.  The unclear was most difficult & it required no little engineering skill to get down.  My pioneering & unclear finally got us down without accident or delay - Once in the bottom however

& go into camp - on a beautiful spot with good wood & water & splendid grass.  Unusually careful about stock today.  We are in the home of the Redman & where where we came into the valley passed the camp of a war party of about 100 strong bound west, probably for Fetterman & the R.R. The camp was about three days old.  Distance today 14 miles.  Total 58 1/2 mi.

We were finally stuck  The bog of the valley becoming impassible - the steep hills on each being broken into bad ravines - almost infeasible to cross or turn - after a deal of work & hauling myself over every route which gave scope of practicability?  I at last determined at 1.20 to stop

by crossing near stream sometimes one, other times the other was resorted to.  Crossed river three times & made the long stretches with the hills -- Crossing abominable- no bottom - bog everywhere.  Made five corduroy & one brush bridge besides a good log bridge over a side stream.  The Com'p did not get out of camp until after 7 am.

My cavalry is very finely mounted & my unclear as food as I have ever seen -  29th - Camp 6 - Out early 5.15. looking for route. Pioneer Co out on foot. Had d l meaning devil? of a time.  Ravines had to be unclear-ed by going into the hills or turned

down. As it was a very bad crossing I did not expect the wagons to get over for two hours.  So I sent the ? to pick out a camp below the junction of the branches of the stream. This had so stimulating an effect on all concerned that the whole comd was safely over & in camp by 3 1/2 pm.  Country

& has had a series of long rests? so that men & animals have had an easy day except the pioneer Co, & the wagon mules. On these it has been tough enough - About 2 1/2  a shower came up.  While I was building the last bridge on the branch of Old Woman we have been following

of sign - very warm today until shower - Nice camp water & wood plenty grass excellent - Distance 15 miles Total 73 1/2 mi  30th - Camp 7 - got out early 5.20 with pioneer company everything following soon after - Had a splendid march over long rolling slopes. having only to

not so beautiful as yesterday.  Tertiary deposit unclear very little timber on stream which is a broad shallow Bed 75 ft wide filled with mud or quick sand - No Indians or signs of any except the war party which went west unclear of yesterday.  They came up this creek & left plenty

"Old Woman Fork' of which we have not many pleasant remembrances so far as route is concerned  By a good trail & with only one cutting we came to the South Cheyenne which I immediately crossed - It is a nasty stream of thirty feet in width - bottom sandy - banks mud - Had to corduroy both banks for fifty feet from water

bridge an occasional ravine or cut a bank.  At 10 1/2 arrived at a crossing of the "Old Woman" which ???-ed in dreadfully.  Had to build a corduroy & bridge over 200 feet long.  It took three solid hours of hard work - at about 2 pm we were ready to cross & got over safely bidding good by to the

Eleven hours at work or marching & the animals in harness or under the saddle - but it has been really tiresome only to the pioneer co. Scout? & myself - I am greatly disappointed in the Cheyenne River - It is a miserable insignificant dirty stream affording however evidence of sometimes getting on

got over safely without accident & all in camp on North bank by 4 1/2 pm. - Excellent camp wood & grass abundant & fine - Water muddy & very thick.  Cleared with cactus it is very palatable so we have nothing to complain of.  It has been a hard day. All hands having been over

which was to his delight dead.  We have been following since yesterday noon the trail of a party of immigrants who in 1865 under the Com.d of a man named Sawyer made a route from Sioux City to Montana.  The trail is very plain to be ten years old & is remarkably good considering the country

the rampage - We are camped in a lovely grassy lawn surrounded on all sides by woods of cottonwood - Country not very beautiful but interesting - plenty of fossils bones etc. - Fred? went wild over the lovely flowers & today saw his first rattlesnake, which

Distance today 18 miles Total 91 1/2  miles.  Total distance travelled on the Old Woman Fork 31 miles.  31 May- Camp 8 - Slept splendidly. Though the camp was aroused partially by a shot about midnight.  Scout/Trout? came to my tent some what excited.  I told him not to stampede

I prefer it greatly to the guidance of Joe Merivale who knows nothing of this country - nothing of distance - nothing of boar? hunting for wagons - Saw five black tail.  ['[unclear]] no chance for shot - game very scarce but deer tracks more plenty today.  Thou heretofore

the alarm. Up at Reville- our roster earlier than usual 5.15 - Went but a short distance before the trail struck to river again  This time the crossing was good & no work was needed.  In half a mile had to cross again.  This time at a very bad place which we had to bridge & corduroy for 50 yds?

anybody & he was off after his herd in the darkness.  It appears that one shot is the signal he has established to unclear trouble in the beef herd for which he is responsible.  There was nothing the greater? a "Doboy" recruit having got scared at a loose horse & fired to give

unclear east of us -- that the larger stream passed was the "Dry Fork" - Acting on this I kept down the river making several bridges over ravines until we arrived at the stream which he was sure ought to be west fork & which turned out to be a very small arroyo - The map

Merivale the guide soon after this wanted me to cross again but my mad was up & I told him I would not do so.  I therefore struck for the hills and made a good trail - He is no sort of a a guide - He insisted that the great West fork of the Cheyenne

It has been a lovely day for marching - no sun - yet not raining- The Indians have just found us out. Two smokes were sent up today on edge of Black Hills.  I hope some of these will come in tomorro- my course tomorro is due north - Distance 13 - Total Dis 104 1/2 m.

showing that we are as far east as we ought to be & not knowing the distance to Beaver? I determined to camp, & at 12 n. went into a fine lovely camp on Cheyenne - splendid wood & grass & good water by digging - river very muddy -

killed a rattlesnake today - the first our Fred ever saw alive - He  - Master Fred - is extracting a deal of pleasure out of this trip - unclear all the time & behaves very well generally - Is getting over his disposition to tantrums

Several deer & antelope killed today - Spaulding sent me a nice ham of antelope off which we dined sumptiously - Had camp fire at my tent & nearly all the offs & scientif--?? came around & we had a very pleasant evening - telling stories etc -- --

attributed to the Scientific people being rather crude - I laughingly attached Jenney on them - He expressed a great contempt for the reporter  & said that no one had ever made any such statements - A short time after Davenport came in & I sallied? him on his military knowledge - He colored up & said he was told so &

There is likely to be trouble between the Herald reporter Davenport & the scientific party. In the Herald of 17th appears a letter of Davenport giving a history of the expedition in advance - the letter unclear written from Cheyenne - Some of the remarks about the escort

I think Jenney is an aspiring man - ready to do anything for own advancement. I doubt very much whether he makes a fair & candid statement of the facts in regard to the Blk Hills.  He is a very young man - very boyish in manner & that he has been put in charge of such an expedition

so by a member of the scientific party - No answer was made to this by Jenney who however seemed uncomfortable.  This morning Davenport came to me & said that what he stated in that letter was almost word for word what was told him by Jenney himself & that he did not say so at the time because he wanted to have no trouble

appointed that he has not military com'd of the expedition. I think he is a small man & that he will not only try to arrogate to himself every particle of the credit of the expedition but will cast slurs on every other member of it who he thinks can in any way come in competition with

indicates a job of some kind My opinion is that the report to be made in unclear has been decided upon already at Washington & that the sending him out is the merest blind? - He is undoubtedly a man of some ability but very weak, very jealous & very much dis

Gentleman of culture refinement & sense & it would be far better for the expedition if he were the leader of it - He is most unassuming, quite devoted to his work & a most agreeable gentleman.  Dr Macgillicuddy the Topographer is the next in rank & merit. He is unclear & unclear

him. I treat him with the greatest kindness & do everything for him but I feel that I get no thanks & that he will eventually show unclear -- not while we are together but after he leaves me & comes to make out his report.  His astronomer? asst Capt Tuttle is a

I think Burtie's? map will be better than his- that is as a unclear chart - His will be far more fancy - but very much of it will be grim? green? work.   Davenport the Herald man writes well & has the regular? unclearknack of unclear profile -but he is as green as

unclear up in his business as a professional map maker but runs too much to fancy & pretty.  He sticks? not at outside work for the sake of embellishment - & I think fails, wether? either? in experience or in unclear knowledge of country which is indispensable for a map maker -

him that the hooting of an owl was the songs of Indian women over an approaching fight & scared him almost to death by predicting a hard fight today -  Jenney tells a story on him that Davenport told him that he did not know when we might be attacked.

a gourd, as credulous as a ninny. The young officers have been stuffing him with the most incredible stories - & lately the men have got at it - He is not blessed with a vast amount of courage & the boys keep him in hot water all the time. Last night they persuaded

MacMillan the man of the Inter Ocean NB: Chicago newspaper is of entirely different stamp, very gentlemanly  hard to stuff & with excellent good sense - & tho this is the first time he has been on the plains he takes to it so kindly & well as to win the liking & respect of every one

that he intends to put his "Herald Flag" over his tent so that the Indians would know he was a non-combattant --- I told him yesterday that he was being informed? on by these youngsters & to beware of publishing any stories or rumors coming from them -

top cut off. in camp unclear the astonomer Capt Tuttle to get the unclear - For unclear the day gave him the opportunity to see the sun at the proper time ? it was cloudy and showering all day & rained quite hard in afternoon.  The water of Beaver Ck is wretched - alkali

June 1, 1875 - Camp No. 9. Broke camp 5.20 a - & marched directly north crossed river with little trouble - only two bridges - one so far over tributary of Beaver - struck the latter stream below forks at 9.30 am and went

small {{chum?]] - that is after several patient hours.  I was able to develop only about a dozen of these small fry - I had a talk with Mr Jenney this afternoon & told him we must move camp. the water here would make my men sick very soon

& full of all abominable unclear -  I am grievously disappointed. From the reports of the unclear I expected a lovely stream of pure water filled with fine fish.  On the contrary tho a fine full running stream it is about as nasty as Bitter? Creek itself & has no fish except a

Black Hills will I hope be an earmark of our success in hunting - There were killed after gathering with? this camp 4 elk 3 deer & 1 brown bear about 250 to 300 pounds - So the camp is full of meat & we rejoice in fatness but mourn over the bad water which requires to be mixed -

So we go on North tomorro hoping to find a pure mountain stream - We are just at the door of the great unknown - the Black Hills.  To the North East of us they tower in majesty covered with a fine growth of pines - Our first day in the

top cut off /illegible ---- a talk with the Herald man today.  He is intelligent but ignorant of life of of human nature & a mere child in his contact with the wild unclear of the plains.  Jenney is more sociable today - No Indians yet - They know we are here & their failure to come in is a rather bad sign

The country passed today is of "bad-land" formation that is the ravines have a tendency to cut down very deep with abrupt banks - This is only near the hills. The valleys are broad & covered with excellent grass - It will be some day the grazing ground of miriads? of cattle -

top cut off, first line illegible --- by the Doctors of the expedition (there are two (2) military & several civil doctors) & the head & all curious unclear carried off.  Dr Macgillicuddy of the scientific got the lower jaw which he proposes to take home as a present for a dear friend to be used as a pen holder "To what base uses may

They will get our stock if possible - but I will keep it if I can - Our camp in a thin grove of very old & large cotton wood trees the tops of which have been cut off year after year by the squaws to feed ponies in the winter - In one was an Indian grave which I am sorry to

June 2nd - Camp 10. Broke camp 5.20 am  Had to bridge Beaver Ck which occupied about an hour & then to cut down the banks of a large tributary from the North which joins main stream less than a mile from camp - Soon afer struck the great North-South Indian Trail - from

we come at last." The jaw bone of a Native Chief to assist in the midnight oil business - Cold & blustery in afternoon & evening - Had fine camp fire - most everybody around it - Distance today 9 2/3  Total 114 1/6 miles from Fort Laramie -

top cut off the march westing today.  In doing this we followed up a middle branch of Beaver which resulted in taking us away from the mountains & by 11 am we were at least 1 1/2 miles too far west.  In a conversation at lunch with Prof Tuttle & Dr Macgillicuddy they told me that they had

the White? River country to the Powder River country.  It is as large & wide as a country road?- From astronomical observations it was found yesterday that we were 4 1/2 miles too far east - that is we were in Dacotah - Mr Jenney unclear -ed therefore to make

top cut off/illegible ----- good grass for the comfort of all plenty of wood - In addition he wanted to work in the mountains & he wanted the camp on 104 long - which would not go into the mountains. He must either abandon good wood water & grass or mountain work for 104 - or abandon 104 for these.  He is an indecisive

no orders to run the west line of Dacotah & had not the instruments to do it - On this hint? I spoke to Jenney - I told him that there were too many points to his problem - we must for the health of the men have good water for the strength of the

top line cut off --- in crossing the bad arroyos I --drately moved? to the creek & went unclear-- camp about 12 n.  The branch of Beaver we are on does not run here but stands in long narrow water holes in which there is no life - not a fish to be caught though I tried faithfully

man & hemmed & hawed on the proposition - He is a mere boy in experience & has still the boyish hope of getting everything just as he desires -  At last however he decided to give up 104 & as we had got a very considerable distance from the mountains & as the train had got

[[top line cut off] I must send my train back & promptly - my Com'd is rationed to 28th & it will take 20 days for the train to go & come so I have only six days for accidents - He saw it all & tomorrow we strike straight for the mountains for what appears to be a pass & is practicable

It is not so alkaline as the main Beaver but is not good water - Wood not abundant but enough for camp - Grass good - I am very glad that I finally settled with Mr J - We have been piddling along a few miles a day hoping to suit all his ideas - I told him I

top line cut off --- to have seen Indians.  All have orders to treat them kindly & bring them in camp if possible - There are very few Indians in vicinity no recent trails have been seen on this creek.  Distance today 10 1/2 miles. Total 124 4/6 -- Day pleasant camp fire & genial evening.

for horsemen - I hope to find a decent place for my permanent camp.  Spaulding went hunting today. Saw 5 elk & a mountain lion but got nothing.  Burt killed an Elk & 1 antelope was brought in by one of the men- Game is only tolerably abundant. Some of

missing top line?? arroyos to bridge with sap brush - arrived at a gorge of the mountains at 1010 & went into camp in a most beautiful spot on a lovely stream of water - pure for this part of the world - & as defensible as any position I have ever seen -  If I had had the making of the spot I could not have suited?

June 3rd Camp 11.  Broke camp 5.20 am & struck at once for the mountains- as nearly as I could conjecture to a pass from which comes the larger East fork which we forded yesterday - The march was an excellent one - nothing bad to cross & only a

better all my ideas of what we want in our permanent camp - Just as I arrived in camp I met with a disaster in the shape of a tumble from my horse which "bucked?" me off in a moment & finished the job by stepping on me with both fore feet - One gentle? unclear on the arm - I will remember

for - He is visionary? & so full of vanity that it requires tact to manage him & so disposed to say ill notions or impertinent things that I have hard work not to go back on him -- I wish I could get rid of him - unclear the details for work tomorrow - must build my storehouse & also two illegible The geologist is delegated? with the [[unclear] I have

so far & hope we will get through the night safely. I must again express my delight at the efficiency of my command & the illegible all officers take in my miles?. I am teaching them plains travel & all appreciate my capacity in that particular - One Elk killed today - I went out fishing but had no proper bait & got nothing

June 4- Camp 11 - Had revielle? an hour late this morning & woke to find Master Fred reading in bed, the extra hour being too much for him - after breakfast went to work on Storehouse - made details illegible

There was a vast amount of work done by all today that is all the working men.  I wrote my reports to Genls Crook &Y Bradley, letter to Father & Mother then visited Burt & Munson? & bade them good by - came back & wrote a long letter to
Camp Jenney - 11 - June 5, 1875. Up pretty early but not soon enough to see the train start - Mr Jenney asked for as escort to to into bottom cut off --hills?

elk and unclear deer - Other parties brought in game. Spaudling's hunter three deer. / So that I do not know how much has been killed today - A great deal however - I moved unclear tents this am, & have now got a beautiful bottom line cut off

& grouping as can be imagined? - I have got out of the draught of the canon & we have now but little wind - I am delighted with the changes except that now lying in my bed & listening to the murmuring of the stream, only fifty feet away, I cannot but

The unclear are in a fair way but the men have been very slow in getting logs today - I will go for them tomorro but it will take me two days yet to finish them to my satisfaction. Show of gold said to have been found runs off page

quiet & allowed himself to be handled & felt of by us all.  I felt sorry for the poor beast, especially as his fur was of no account at this season & persuaded them to turn it loose - we then drove it quietly to the water
creek - One of his number had come down to where he could see the camp & went back in a hurry.  They were travelling south - another trail of a party of 15 or 20 was found
of game and one of his hunters told me that he had never seen so many deer in one day in his life - Six or seven bear were also seen but none killed today - Fred is delighted as

Camp Jenney 11 - June 6, 1875 Sunday
Slept rather late - after breakfast I went up to the unclear & got the walls started. It is slow work however the logs being hard to get at. They grow well up on
both unclear in the two days - Quiet lovley day - several deer killed - In fact we over overloaded with meat. Red & took a nap in afternoon - Joe Merivlale the guide returns about 3 1;2 pm
is too small for the subdivision which would be required to send all their parties in to Fort Laramie. The weather has been unusually cold & dis{unclear}
& we talked over the route of our scout. I am to go out with him tomrro on a flyer to see how the land lays & whether we can get through the Hills into the

Camp Jenney
Long 104 degrees - 19.' 30"
Lat 43 degrees -50'-12"
Camp 11 - 1st Permanent
